Graphical abstract Alkylaluminium is one of the components of the Ziegler-Natta catalysts, which plays a significant role in the active materials with different regions and stereoselectivity. The polymerization of isoprene with alkylaluminium in TiCl4/MgCl2 type Ziegler-Natta catalysts system is rarely studied by simulation. In this work, density functional theory (DFT) was applied to investigate the mechanism of the polymerization of isoprene with heterogeneous Ziegler-Natta catalyst in the presence and absence of AlEt2Cl on the surface of MgCl2 (110). The interaction between AlEt2Cl and MgCl2 support was studied by the counterpoise corrected approach. Two active models were adopted to analyze the influence of AlEt2Cl on the polymerization of isoprene in the coordination process and the insertion process respectively. The calculations indicated that only one double bond of isoprene was coordinated to the active center, the presence of AlEt2Cl improved the stereoselectivity of the active center, increased the difficulty of cis coordination, and reduced the difficulty of trans coordination. In the insertion process, the cis insertion process was more favorable and the trans product structure was more stable. Keywords Heterogeneous Ziegler-Natta catalyst Isoprene Catalytic mechanism Active species DFT 1 Introduction Polyolefins as the most important commodities with low prices and excellent comprehensive properties have been widely used in the fields like packaging, automotive, medicine, construction, and equipment [1], and heterogeneous TiCl4/MgCl2 type Ziegler-Natta catalysts contribute greatly to the large production of polyolefins [1–3]. The heterogeneous TiCl4/MgCl2 type Ziegler-Natta catalysts are mainly composed of MgCl2, TiCl4, electron donors, and alkylaluminium [4]. Numerous theoretical simulations [5–11] and experimental studies [12–22] have been conducted on the interaction between the components in TiCl4/MgCl2 type Ziegler-Natta catalysts. Potapov et al. [23] pointed out that TiCl4 could migrate inside and outside the catalyst particles, and TiCl4 was the real precursor of the active sites. Busico, Monaco, Zorve and their coworker [24–28] showed that the TiCl4 adsorption on the surface of MgCl2 (110) was thermodynamically stable by using density functional theory (DFT). Ziegler [29] summarized the three possible models of TiCl4 on MgCl2, namely Corradini, Slope and Edge, and DFT calculation indicated the TiCl4 adsorbed on MgCl2 named Corradini model was the most stable. Cheng Ruihua et al. [6] calculated 10 possible chlorine defect models on (110) and (100) surfaces of MgCl2 crystals, and then established the most probable active center model. Piovano et al. [30] proved the existence of the complex of the electron donor and alkylaluminium binding near the titanium species by the combination of experiment and calculation. Breuza et al. [31] reported the formation of adducts between MgCl2 and three internal donors through a flexible cluster. Correa et al. [9] discussed the stereoselectivity and regioselectivity of the active species model with and without three electron donors. As the reducing agent, alkylaluminium also participates in the catalytic polymerization reaction, which affects the stereospecificity of the polymer [32–34]. Cavallo et al. [35] used DFT to simulate the energy of alkylation and reduction of TiCl4 and proposed that aluminum was the most effective reduction agent. Boero et al. [7] used the first-principles molecular dynamics method to study the mechanism of Ziegler-Natta catalyst for ethylene polymerization. MgCl2/Ti3+Cl2Et was the possible active center for α-olein polymerization [36]. Potapov et al. [37,38] used 27Al NMR MAS to find that AlEt2Cl was the main alkylaluminium compounds adsorbed on the catalyst surface. Fan Zhiqiang et al. [18] found that AlEt2Cl would be adsorbed on the Mg adjacent to the active center Ti through two Cl bridges during the polymerization of propylene. Zhong Chifeng et al. [39] discussed three types of polypropylene: isotactic, atactic, and syndiotactic. Credendino et al. [40] pointed out that the presence of AlEt2Cl increased the stereoselectivity and regioselectivity of primary propylene insertion by using TiCl4/MgCl2 type Ziegler-Natta catalysts. Although numerous works have been studied to illustrate the composition relationship of Ziegler-Natta catalyst and α-olefin polymerization, few works are reported on the application of Ziegler-Natta catalyst in isoprene polymerization, especially the role of alkylaluminium compounds in isoprene polymerization. Our previous [19–22] work found that a mixture with high cis-1,4 structure was obtained at the initial stage of polymerization, which was attributed to the active centers C*-2 with low steric hinderance. With the adsorption of AlEt2Cl on the Mg adjacent to the Ti, active species C*-2 with high steric hinderance were gradually transformed from C*-1 and finally became the dominate species which yielded high trans-1,4-polymers. However, the above mechanism is a hypothesis. In this work, DFT was applied to calculate the effect of AlEt2Cl in the process of polymerizing isoprene in the TiCl4/MgCl2 solid pre-catalysts for the first time. It is expected to establish the more convincible model for isoprene polymerization by using the heterogeneous Ziegler-Natta catalyst. 2 Models and computational details 2.1 Active site models The initial model of the active center was established (Fig. 1 ) based on the active center model screened and established by Cheng Ruihua et al. [6]. This initial model of active center with low steric hindrance was shown in Fig. 2 A (known as C*-2 formerly), and the initial model of active center adsorbed AlEt2Cl with high steric hindrance was shown in Fig. 2B (known as C*-1 formerly). The mechanism of isoprene polymerization was explored by freezing MgCl2 cluster edge atoms and relaxing other atoms. 2.2 DFT calculation All calculations were performed by using the Gaussian09 [41] software. The active center was Ti3+, so an unlimited DFT calculation was performed when considered the insertion of isoprene into the Ti-Et groups to simulate the growth of primary polymer chain. The B3LYP hybrid density functional [42,43] was used for all geometry calculations with the dispersion correction [44,45](keywords：em = gd3bj). For all geometry optimizations, def2-SVP basis was used for Mg, Cl, C, H and Al atoms, and SDD pseudopotential basis was used for metal Ti atom. The frequencies of each optimized structure were calculated and characterized as a minimum state (Nimag = 0) or transition state (Nimag = 1) at the same theoretical level. The transition states were calculated by intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) to verify the accuracy of the reaction route. The extracted structures of the complex and the product were further optimized from the IRC calculation. The M06−2X [46] was used for all single point energy calculations with the dispersion correction [44,45](keywords: em = gd3), and def2-TZVPP was used for Mg, Cl, C, H, and Al atoms, while the other atomic groups remained unchanged. All the energies involved in this paper are discussed in terms of the Gibbs free energy. The reference point on the potential energy surface was the free energy sum of the active species model A or B and trans isoprene monomers to facilitate unified benchmarks and data analysis of the four insertion modes. The 3D models were drawn with CYLview [47] software in this paper. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 AlEt2Cl adsorption Since AlEt2Cl is easy to form dimer at room temperature, the dissociation free energy of (AlEt2Cl)2 should be considered when discussing the adsorption of AlEt2Cl. For the calculation of adsorption energy, the bases set superposition error (BSSE) was introduced considering the incompleteness of the base set. The adsorption energy of AlEt2Cl (Eadsor ) was given according to Eq. (1): (1) E a d s o r = E B - E A 0 + E A l E t 2 C l 0 + B S S E Where, EB represents the energy of model B, E A 0 represents the energy of model A, E A l E t 2 C l 0 represents the energy of AlEt2Cl, BSSE represents the BSSE energy. The Eadsor was analyzed by the energy decomposition theory for the convenience of analysis, and the electron energy was divided into deformation energy and interaction energy. Eq. (1) could be replaced by Eq. (2): (2) E a d s o r = E d e f + E int e r Where, Edef represents deformation energy, Einter represents corrected interaction energy. Edef could be calculated according to Eqs. (3)–(5)): (3) E d e f = E d e f ( A ) + E d e f ( A l E t 2 C l ) (4) E d e f ( A ) = E A - E A 0 (5) E d e f ( A l E t 2 C l ) = E A l E t 2 C l - E A l E t 2 C l 0 Where EA represents the energy of deformed model A. E A l E t 2 C l represents the energy of deformed AlEt2Cl. The above equations are also applicable to the G value. The calculation results of adsorption of AlEt2Cl in model B were presented in Table 1 . The dissociation free energy of the (AlEt2Cl)2 was 18.5 kcal/mol. The deformation free energy of model A (Gdef(A) ) was 5.0 kcal/mol according to Eq. (4), The deformation free energy of AlEt2Cl ( G d e f ( A l E t 2 C l ) ) was 12.2 kcal/mol according to Eq. (5), and it could further calculate that the adsorption free energy (Gadsor ) was -18.6 kcal/mol according to Eq. (2), the free energy of the whole process was -0.1 kcal/mol. 3.2 Isoprene coordination and insertion The polymerization process of isoprene was divided into three steps: (1) isoprene was coordinated to the active center to form complexes; (2) the complexes reacted to the transition states; (3) isoprene was inserted into the active center of Ti-Et to form products. Being a prochiral molecule, isoprene monomer was coordinated to Ti center with a variety of coordination modes. Combined the results of previous experiments [19,20], the mixed structure with high cis-1,4 structure was obtained in the initial stage of isoprene polymerization, and the mixed structure with high trans-1,4 structure was obtained in the later stage of polymerization. The coordination and insertion processes of isoprene on models A and B with cis-1,4-si, cis-1,4-re, trans-1,4-si and trans-1,4-re were investigated in this paper, and the effect of AlEt2Cl on the stereoselectivity of the active center was explored. 3.2.1 Isoprene coordination and insertion on model A with low steric hinderance Full transition state search for isoprene polymerization on model A with cis-1, 4-si, cis-1, 4-re, trans-1, 4-si and trans-1, 4-re four insertion modes were conducted, and the transition state structures involved were shown in Fig. 3 a, b, c and d. The label of carbon atoms in the model were shown in Fig. 3e. The main bond distances Bi (i = 1…, 9) in the complexes and transition states were summarized as shown in Table 2 , in which B1 was the bond distance between C1 and Ti, B2 was the bond distance between C2 and Ti, B3 was the bond distance between C3 and Ti, B4 was the bond distance between C4 and Ti, B5 was the bond distance between C1 and C2, B6 was the bond distance between C2 and C3, B7 was the bond distance between C3 and C4, B8 was the bond distance between C4 and Cα, and B9 was the bond distance between Cα and Ti. The free energies of complexes, transition states and products were calculated, and the results were shown in Fig. 4 . Reaction began with the π complex of isoprene, the isoprene monomer was coordinated to the transition center metal Ti. As shown in Table 2, the distances of B1 (C1-Ti), B2 (C2-Ti), B3 (C3-Ti) and B4 (C4-Ti) were 2.47–2.61 Å, 2.92–2.99 Å, 3.57–3.68 Å and 4.18–4.66 Å when isoprene were coordinated with cis-1,4-si, cis-1,4-re, trans-1,4-si and trans-1,4-re, these data indicated that C3 and C4 were far away from Ti atom, and only the C1-C2 bond of isoprene was coordinated to the central metal Ti. The distance of the two double bonds of isoprene (B5 and B7) were elongated and the distance of the single bond (B6) was shortened when the reaction reached the transition state, which showed that all three bonds of isoprene were activated. It could also be clearly seen that the distance of B9 (Cα-Ti) has been elongated, the distance of B8 (C4-Cα) in isoprene was getting closer, and the distance of B1 (C1-Ti)in isoprene was 2.21–2.28 Å, which proved that the bond of C1-Ti was formed gradually. Compared the distance of B9 (Cα-Ti) in the cis and trans configurations, it could be found that there was almost no difference in the complexes (2.05 and 2.06 Å versus 2.04 and 2.04 Å), but the distance of B9 in the trans configurations (3.02 and 2.99 Å) was significantly longer than the cis configurations (2.22 and 2.21 Å) when it came to the transition state, which might be due to the difference in the configuration of isoprene. The free energy of isoprene coordination on model A were -1.5 kcal/mol, -2.0 kcal/mol, 1.3 kcal/mol and -4.2 kcal/mol with cis-1,4-si, cis-1,4-re, trans-1,4-si and trans-1,4-re as shown in Fig. 4, respectively, which were all stable coordination. The coordinate free energy of re isoprene (-2.0 and -4.2 kcal/mol) was lower than that of si isoprene (1.3 and -1.5 kcal/mol). The free energy barrier of isoprene inserted into the active center A with cis-1,4-si, cis-1,4-re, trans-1,4-si and trans-1,4-re were 35.9 kcal/mol, 35.4 kcal/mol, 35.3 kcal/mol and 39.8 kcal/mol, respectively. According to the transition state theory that the free energy barrier was lower, the reaction was much easier to happen, it could obvious seen that the free energy barrier of trans isoprene insertion (35.3 and 39.8 kcal/mol) was higher than that of cis isoprene insertion (35.9 and 35.4 kcal/mol), therefore, the cis isoprene insertion process was favorable when AlEt2Cl had not been absorbed on model A with low steric hindrance. The free energy barrier of si/re insertion process of cis isoprene with 35.9 kcal/mol and 35.4 kcal/mol were further compared, the difference between the two types (ΔGstereo ) was only 0.5 kcal/mol, it indicated that the possibility of re and si insertion was similar in the cis isoprene polymerization process, which further pointed that the model A had no stereoselectivity. Therefore, if we want a product with a specific structure, we need to introduce other substances on the active center to change the constitutive selectivity of the active center to get the target product. The above simulation results demonstrated that the cis configuration was more dominant in the coordination and insertion process. It further showed that the cis products accounted for a large proportion of the model A polymerization product, which was consistent with the experimental results. 3.2.2 Isoprene coordination and insertion on model B with high steric hinderance Full transition state search for isoprene polymerization on model B with cis-1, 4-si, cis-1, 4-re, trans-1, 4-si and trans-1, 4-re four insertion modes were also conducted in order to further understand the effect of AlEt2Cl on the polymerization of isoprene, and the transition state structures were shown in Fig. 5 a, b, c, and d. The free energies of complexes, transition states and products were calculated, and the results were shown in Fig. 6 . The free energy of isoprene coordination on B were -4.8 kcal/mol, -7.1 kcal/mol, -7.7 kcal/mol and -10.3 kcal/mol with cis-1,4-si, cis-1,4-re, trans-1,4-si and trans-1,4-re as shown in Fig. 6, respectively, which were all stable coordination. The coordinate free energy of trans isoprene (-7.7 and -10.3 kcal/mol) was lower than that of cis isoprene (-4.8 and -7.1 kcal/mol), and isoprene monomer was more likely to coordinate with the central metal Ti in trans configuration. The free energy barrier of isoprene inserted into the active center B with cis-1,4-si, cis-1,4-re, trans-1,4-si and trans-1,4-re were 34.9 kcal/mol, 36.1 kcal/mol, 45.9 kcal/mol and 45.5 kcal/mol, respectively. According to the transition state theory, it was obvious seen that the free energy barrier of trans isoprene insertion (45.9 and 45.5 kcal/mol) was higher than that of cis isoprene insertion (34.9 and 36.1 kcal/mol), therefore, the cis isoprene insertion process was also favorable when AlEt2Cl has been absorbed in model B with high steric hindrance. The free energy barrier of si/re insertion process of cis isoprene with 34.9 kcal/mol and 36.1 kcal/mol were further compared, the different between the two types (ΔGstereo ) was 1.2 kcal/mol, it indicated that the presence of AlEt2Cl improved the stereoselectivity of the model B. The reason for the small stereoselectivity improvement may be the small alkyl size and the smaller increase of steric hindrance in alkylaluminium. The above simulation results indicated that the trans configuration was dominant in the coordination process, and the cis configuration was dominant in the insertion phase. Compared the coordination free energy data in Figs. 4 and 6, the coordination free energy of cis-1,4-si isoprene was decreased by 3.3 kcal/mol, the coordination free energy of cis-1,4-re isoprene was decreased by 5.1 kcal/mol, the coordination free energy of trans-1,4-si isoprene was decreased 9.0 kcal/mol, the coordination free energy of trans-1,4-re isoprene was decreased 6.1 kcal/mol with AlEt2Cl adsorption, the data indicated that the activity of the catalyst was improved with AlEt2Cl adsorption. In terms of the relative degree of data improvement, it could be seen that the presence of AlEt2Cl made the coordination of cis isoprene became more difficult, made the coordination of trans isoprene easier. The free energy of the products involved in the four processes were lower than that of the reactants, so the insertion processes were thermodynamically exothermic, and the trans product was more stable. Which indicated that the adsorption of AlEt2Cl reduced the cis-trans ratio in the product, which was consistent with the experimental results. In addition to alkylaluminium could affect the stereoselectivity of heterogeneous Z-N catalysts, surface coordinated titanium, and electron donors could affect the stereoselectivity of heterogeneous Z-N catalysts. Alkylaluminium and electron donor can also be adsorbed at the same time to affect the stereoselectivity of the catalyst. The surface of the catalyst is complex and diverse, the effect of AlEt2Cl on isoprene polymerization was discussed in this paper. 4 Conclusion This paper studied the polymerization process of isoprene in the heterogeneous Ziegler-Natta catalytic system using DFT, focused on the effect of AlEt2Cl on the polymerization process. The results indicated that the free energy of the whole process from the dissociation of the (AlEt2Cl)2 to the adsorption to the (110) surface of MgCl2 was -0.1 kcal/mol. The cis isoprene was more easily coordinated and insertion on model A without AlEt2Cl adsorption, and model A had no stereoselectivity. The trans isoprene (-7.7and -10.3 kcal/mol) was more easily coordinated on B with AlEt2Cl adsorption. In terms of free energy barrier of both models in the process of isoprene insertion, it was found that cis isoprene was more favorable than trans isoprene, because the former had a lower free energy barrier. Compared the data of the two models, it was found that the presence of AlEt2Cl improved the stereoselectivity (ΔGstereo = 0.5 kcal/mol versus ΔGstereo = 1.2 kcal/mol) of the active center, and changed the proportion of cis-trans products. This study contributes to a better understanding of the mechanism of isoprene polymerization by heterogeneous Ziegler-Natta catalyst, and provides a basis for the design of heterogeneous Ziegler-Natta catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Alkylaluminium is one of the components of the Ziegler-Natta catalysts, which plays a significant role in the active materials with different regions and stereoselectivity. The polymerization of isoprene with alkylaluminium in TiCl4/MgCl2 type Ziegler-Natta catalysts system is rarely studied by simulation. In this work, density functional theory (DFT) was applied to investigate the mechanism of the polymerization of isoprene with heterogeneous Ziegler-Natta catalyst in the presence and absence of AlEt2Cl on the surface of MgCl2 (110). The interaction between AlEt2Cl and MgCl2 support was studied by the counterpoise corrected approach. Two active models were adopted to analyze the influence of AlEt2Cl on the polymerization of isoprene in the coordination process and the insertion process respectively. The calculations indicated that only one double bond of isoprene was coordinated to the active center, the presence of AlEt2Cl improved the stereoselectivity of the active center, increased the difficulty of cis coordination, and reduced the difficulty of trans coordination. In the insertion process, the cis insertion process was more favorable and the trans product structure was more stable.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of AlEt2Cl on the polymerization of isoprene using TiCl4/MgCl2 type Ziegler-Natta catalyst: A DFT study
